importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the latest update in the case, indicating ongoing legal proceedings in Canada regarding a contested election result.
The date of the April 2025 federal election in which the contested result occurred.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe of the federal election in which the electoral district of Terrebonne was contested, leading to the legal challenge over a single uncounted vote.
The current phase of the legal proceedings, with a three-day hearing underway in Quebec’s Superior Court to determine whether the election result should be overturned.

keyTakeAways: A single vote was not counted due to an administrative error involving a wrongly printed postal code on ballots, raising questions about election integrity.
The vote in the Terrebonne district was won by just one vote, making it a pivotal case in Canadian electoral law and public trust in democratic processes.
The legal challenge highlights the tension between procedural errors and the fundamental right to vote, with implications for voter confidence and the legitimacy of close election results.
The case is being litigated in Quebec’s Superior Court, with both candidates’ legal teams arguing that overturning or preserving the result would have broader implications for democratic norms.
Elections Canada has acknowledged that such errors are inevitable in large-scale voting systems, but the case may influence future protocols to prevent similar mistakes.

namedEntities.name: Tatiana Auguste
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Liberal Party candidate who won the Terrebonne electoral district by a single vote.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her narrow victory, won by just one vote, formed a key part of the political outcome and triggered the legal challenge over an uncounted vote.

namedEntities.name: Nathalie Sinclair-Desgagné
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Bloc Québécois incumbent who lost the Terrebonne seat by one vote and challenged the election result.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She challenged the result after a voter claimed her ballot was not counted, making her central to the legal dispute over vote legitimacy.

namedEntities.name: Emmanuelle Bossé
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Terrebonne resident who reported her mail-in ballot was returned to sender due to an incorrect postal code.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her ballot was not counted due to an administrative error, and she is a key figure in the case as the source of the claimed uncounted vote.

namedEntities.name: Mark Carney
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Prime Minister of Canada and leader of the ruling Liberal Party.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Carney's party gained a narrow majority in the election, and the outcome in Terrebonne contributed to their overall legislative majority.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. President, cited in the article as influencing the election environment.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His threats to impose tariffs and annex Canada were mentioned as a factor that energized the Liberal Party's campaign and influenced voter sentiment.

namedEntities.name: Elections Canada
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Canadian federal body responsible for administering elections.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is responsible for the administrative error (wrong postal code) and is defending the integrity of the electoral process in court.

namedEntities.name: Terrebonne
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Electoral district in Quebec, north of Montreal, that was the focus of the one-vote race.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This district is the focal point of the legal challenge due to its extremely narrow margin of victory.

namedEntities.name: Quebec Superior Court
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The court where the legal challenge is currently being heard.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is the venue where the legal dispute over whether the election result should be overturned is being resolved.

namedEntities.name: Stéphane Chatigny
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He argued that overturning the result would undermine public confidence in the electoral system.

namedEntities.name: Marc-Étienne Vien
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He argued that cancelling the result would violate the right to vote for thousands of residents.

namedEntities.name: David Baum
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He emphasized that errors are inevitable in complex electoral systems and that the process is not designed for perfection.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A close election in Canada’s Terrebonne district, won by just one vote, has sparked a legal challenge after a voter, Emmanuelle Bossé, reported her mail-in ballot was not counted due to an administrative error—specifically, a mistakenly printed postal code on ballots by Elections Canada. The case is now being heard in Quebec’s Superior Court, with both candidates' legal teams arguing over the legitimacy of the result: the Bloc Québécois incumbent Nathalie Sinclair-Desgagné claims overturning the result is necessary to maintain public trust, while the Liberal candidate Tatiana Auguste’s legal team argues that invalidating the result denies the right to vote. The incident raises broader concerns about the integrity of electoral systems, especially in extremely narrow races, and highlights the tension between procedural errors and democratic legitimacy.
title: A blunder meant this voter’s ballot wasn’t counted – then her pick lost by one vote. Now the case is in court
